III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
Section (1) An agency shall only place a child with an adult who is legally
Description related to the child, is a legal custodian, or in a licensed foster
home, except as permitted in R 400.12709.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A temporary court ward (TCW) that listed as being placed in a
licensed foster home, however, was really staying in a different
home with a substitute caregiver who was attempting to become
licensed. This lasted well over a month. MIC ended up
substantiating the substitute caregiver who was attempting to
become licensed. The licensed foster home is licensed through
Lapeer County, but the TCW is a ward out of Oakland County.
2

Investigation The reporting source had no additional information to provide
other than what was stated in the allegation.
Several attempts were made to contact the foster parent of Youth
A. The foster parent did not make herself available for an
interview. The telephone number provided was not accessible to
leave a message for a call back.
The Foster Care Worker was interviewed via telephone on
1/23/2023. She reported the history of Youth A. Oakland County
DHHS has full responsibility for Youth A. She reported Youth A
was placed in a licensed foster home (Lapeer County DHHS) from
10/11/2022 – 12/7/2022. She reported Youth A has severe
mental health behaviors and had a long history of aggression and
self-harm behaviors. These behaviors included running into the
street attempting to be hit by cars, banging his had hard against a
hard surface, making suicidal and homicidal statements,
destruction of property, defiant behaviors and verbal and physical
aggression towards children and adults.
The Foster Care Worker reported a foster care action summary
was completed on Youth A on 10/11/22. She reported the reason
for the change of placement from his parent was due to the
parent’s mental health status and making threats against MDHHS,
Guardian Ad Litem (GAL), other workers, and the referee. It was
reported that Youth A was placed with an aunt and cousin but had
to be removed due to his behaviors. MDHHS reached out to other
relatives and fictive kin for placement, but no one was willing to
take Youth A.
The Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed via
TEAMS on 1/23/2023. She said Youth A was placed in a licensed
foster home on 10/11/2022. However, the foster home Youth A
was placed in had three other children in the home with behavioral
issues. She said the foster parent had a friend who lived very
close who offered to be the substitute caregiver for Youth A.
The Foster Care Supervisor reported that the substitute
caregiver that was willing to assist the foster parent with Youth A
was in the process of being licensed through Lapeer County
DHHS. It was discussed by DHHS License of Lapeer County and
the Foster Care of Oakland County DHHS that when the
substitute caregiver receives her license, Youth A will be placed in
the home of the substitute caregiver because she will become a
license foster home. The FCS explained that Lapeer County
3

DHHS Licensing Supervisor reported they had a large caseload
and would not be able to approve the home study quickly. The
substitute caregiver 3130 was completed by Lapeer County DHHS
in September of 2022. Therefore, Oakland County Licensing
agreed to take the case and complete any additional work that
was needed to get the substitute caregiver licensed so that Youth
A could be place in the home of the substitute caregiver as a
permanent placement.
The FCS explained that when Oakland County DHHS received
the case from Lapeer County DHHS, it was in the beginning of the
DHHS system change to CWLM. Oakland County DHHS could
not update the case or route the assessment of the substitute
caregiver from Lapeer County to Oakland County DHHS because
there was a delay with the system and Oakland County DHHS did
not have access to route the 3130 for completion. A helpdesk
ticket was created to assist with helping to license the substitute
caregiver’s home. The FCS said when Oakland County DHHS
received the access to route the 3130, the case would be
transferred back to Lapeer County DHHS as a licensed foster
home of the substitute caregiver and Youth A would be permanent
place with the substitute caregiver due to the substitute caregiver
becoming a licensed foster home.
The Foster Care Supervisor and Foster Care Worker were
consistent in reporting at no time did Youth A spend long periods
of time at the substitute caregiver’s home during this process. The
FCS said Youth A would spend time at the substitute caregiver
home several times a month for several hours and return home to
his licensed foster parent’s home. She said the substitute
caregiver would pick Youth A up from school sometimes and
transport him to appointments such as therapist appointment that
was scheduled to assist the foster parent who cared for three
other youths placed in her home. The FCS could not identify the
dates Youth A was transported or the dates he spent the several
hours in the substitute caregiver home. However, she was
adamant in stating that Youth A was not living or staying with the
substitute caregiver on a consistent basis but did go to the
substitute caregiver home to play video games and to deescalate
if he was feeling anxious at the home of his foster parent and
needed to get away. The FCS said Youth A had bonded with the
substitute caregiver.
FCS said Youth A was approved for the Serious Emotional
Disturbance Waiver through Genesee Health System and 120
4

hours of substitute caregiver placement per month through
Genesee Health System.
The FCS said the foster parent and the substitute caregiver made
and agreed to the arrangements. The FCS said Lapeer Licensing
Supervisor, the GAL and the courts were aware of these
arrangements. The FCS reported there was a Team Decision
Making (TDM) that took place on September 23, 2022, whereby
Lapeer County DHHS agreed to allowed Youth A in the substitute
caregiver home to provide support to the foster parent due to the
concerns of the behaviors of Youth A. FCS reported that the
parent, GAL, Lapeer Licensing Supervisor, Oakland County
Licensing Supervisor, foster care worker and foster care
supervisor were in attendance. The FCS reported that the
substitute caregiver, and the foster parent were involved in Youth
A's Wraparound meetings, therapy appointments, as well as
attended Youth A’s court hearing that was held in November
2022. FCS said this was all in the effort to help with the eventual
transition of Youth A to the substitute caregiver’s home upon the
substitute caregiver getting licensed.
I reviewed a report written by DHHS dated 11/30/2022. The
report stated that on 11/22/2022, 911 was dispatched for a well-
being check on Youth A. Youth A was almost hit by a car trying to
cross a busy road. The allegation was that Youth A had an
altercation with one of his peers at school. The substitute
caregiver picked Youth A up from school and transported him to
her home. Upon arriving at the substitute caregiver home, the
substitute caregiver put Youth A on punishment and took his toys.
Youth A got upset and begin destroying the bedroom and
attempted to jump out of the window. The substitute caregiver
grabbed Youth A by his shirt to prevent him from jumping out of
the window. Later, Youth A ran away, and the substitute caregiver
ran after Youth A as Youth A ran into the road. The substitute
caregiver grabbed Youth A again by his shirt to prevent him from
getting hit by a car. Youth A disclosed to the dispatcher that the
substitute caregiver was physically abusing him. It was found that
Youth A has some small abrasions around his neck from his shirt
being pulled by the substitute caregiver. Youth A also had some
superficial scratches on his neck due to substitute caregiver
grabbing Youth A by his shirt to prevent him from jumping out of
the window and preventing him from running into the road. It is
written in the report that Youth A ran away a second time, and the
substitute caregiver did not go after Youth A to bring him back to
her home, instead, Youth A was returned back to the home by two
unknown males. The recommendation of the report is that it was
5

confirmed and substantiated as a category III with a moderate risk
for improper supervision. This was due to the substitute caregiver
not attempting or looking for Youth A when he ran away from her
home the second time.
It should be noted that when the above allegation was made,
Youth A did not go back to the substitute caregiver home.
The Substitute Caregiver is not licensed through Lapeer County
DHHS or Oakland County DHHS. She is no longer interested in
the process.
FCS reported that Youth A was sent to the emergency on 12/7/22
due to suicidal concerns. The FCS said Youth A was released
from the hospital and placed with Harbor Oaks Hospital on
12/28/2022. She said upon Youth A’s release, Youth A will be
placed with another licensed foster home who does not have other
youths in the home with similar behaviors as Youth A.
Documents reviewed:
Youth A’s case record in MiSACWIS was reviewed on 1/24/2023.
Other than what was reported regarding his behaviors, no other
information was relevant to this investigation.
Foster Parent Case record in CWLM was reviewed on 1/18/2023.
There was a special investigation open on the foster home on
1/17/2023, regarding Youth A and the foster home. There were
no violations found on the foster home.
Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary- this report
summarized the reason for Youth A’s removal from his relatives.
Communication Issuance – 17-168 on Substitute Care. The CI
states that a substitute care provider does not need to be a
licensed provider. This was issued on 12/11/2017.
DHHS investigation report dated 11/30/2022 on the substitute
caregiver home.
Analysis
Based on policy and the Communication Issuance 17-168 on
Substitute Care, a substitute care provider does not need to be a
licensed provider to care for a youth in their home. This is driven
by the need of the substitute care.
Both foster care supervisor and foster care worker were adamant
in stating that Youth A did not live in the home of the substitute
caregiver but assisted Youth A’s licensed foster parent with
transportation of Youth A to his varies appointments and allowed
6

Youth A to come to her home (Substitute Caregiver) to de-
escalate when he felt anxious or needed to get away. In addition,
Youth A had 120 hours of substitute caregiver placement per
month through Genesee Health System.
An allegation was made on the home of the substitute caregiver
by Youth A on 11/30/2022. Youth A was no longer allowed to visit
the home or be transported by the substitute caregiver. The
substitute caregiver was substantiated on improper supervision of
Youth A due to not attempting or looking for Youth A when he ran
away from her home the second time on 11/22/2022.
Based on interviews from staff, documentation, and the
Communication Issuance 17-168 which states, “Approved
Absences from Placement: The following are instances in which
the child can be in an approved absence from their placement that
do not require placement changes or capacity changes to licensed
foster homes.
• Substitute Care: Short term care and supervision for a foster
child in the absence of the caregiver. Substitute care is driven
by the caregiver’s need for substitute care. The substitute
care provider does not need to be a licensed provider. If the
substitute care provider is a licensed provider, a capacity
change does not need to occur.
Youth A was allowed to spend time at the substitute caregiver
home per policy outlined in the communication issuance. The
agency followed DHHS policy regarding a substitute caregiver,
therefore, no violation was established.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that Oakland County DHHS current
license status be continued.
